properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Easterly winds reaching up to 100 kilometres per hour will occur over this community into Friday morning. ### Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-03T11:04:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-02T19:05:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3781504563.2020
Area: Umiujaq
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected today. Rain or snow is expected early this morning with areas along the Ontario-Manitoba border receiving mostly snow while areas farther east more likely to receive rain. Snowfall amounts of 2 to 5 cm are likely along the Ontario-Manitoba border by early morning, with an additional 5 to 10 cm possible for much of the area later today. In addition, there is a risk of freezing rain early this morning as the rain changes to snow. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-04T01:29:44-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-03T09:30:44-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1128187475.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall is expected tonight into Saturday morning. Snow is expected to move from northern Manitoba into the region during the evening hours and continues through the night before tapering of Saturday morning. Total snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are expected by Saturday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain possible tonight. Rain is forecast to transition to a period of freezing rain this evening and then to snow overnight. The freezing rain could persist for a couple of hours and be mixed with ice pellets at times before the change to snow occurs. Ice accretion is most likely on elevated surfaces; however, untreated highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may also become icy and slippery. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-04T01:18:00-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. A slow moving cold front will continue to bring significant snowfall to central and northern Manitoba over the next couple of days. In the south, snow will taper off from west to east throughout the day today. In Winnipeg, the Red River Valley and Interlake, the snow will end some time this morning with further amounts of only a couple of centimetres. It should end this afternoon in the Whiteshell, with up to 4 more centimetres in the forecast, and this evening around Berens River with 5 to 10 more centimetres likely. In the north, snow will continue heavy at times today, then the main area of snow will shift northeastward towards Gillam and Churchill for tonight and Saturday. Total snowfalls of 15 to 25 cm are likely in most areas, although parts of north-central Manitoba could top the 30 cm mark. Finally on Sunday, the snow over northeastern Manitoba should also come to an end as the system finally weakens. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-04T01:36:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-03T09:37:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4108494906.2020

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain expected this morning. Rain is expected to change to freezing rain early this morning. The freezing rain will likely last for several hours before changing to snow near midday Friday. Up to 5 mm of ice accretion or build up is possible. Ice accretion is most likely on elevated surfaces however untreated highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may also become icy and slippery. ### Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-03T20:59:58-00:00

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in blowing snow are expected to continue this morning. As winds weaken, visibilities are expected to improve near noon today. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.

properties.Title: Freezing Drizzle Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Areas of freezing drizzle are expected or occurring. Locations: Northeast-facing coastlines of Newfoundland and adjacent inland areas. Time span: midnight tonight until Friday morning. Remarks: Freezing drizzle is expected to be somewhat patchy tonight as temperatures hover around the freezing mark, but it will be most extensive over higher elevations where temperatures will be 1 to 2 degrees colder than at sea level. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing drizzle advisories are issued when drizzle falling in sub-zero temperatures is expected to freeze on contact, and over time create icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-04-03T16:59:43-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-03T02:17:43-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1629368560.2020
